variant.question: What flight level shall an aircraft hold, according to SERA, when flying IFR?
An aircraft must always have one of its altimeters before departure set to

options.text: QNH
QFF
QDR
QFE

variant.question: An IFR flight is cruising at 12 000 ft. The transition altitude in the region is currently 18 000 ft. When ATC requests the vertical position of the aircraft, what should it be reported as?

options.text: Altitude.
Elevation.
Height.
Flight Level.

variant.question:
An aircraft is maintaining FL150 within airspace class C
Another aircraft below at FL140 is receiving a clearance to descend to FL70
What is the earliest time that a clearance to descend to FL140 or below can be expected?

options.text: When the other aircraft has reported that it has left FL140.
When the other aircraft has reported that it has reached FL70.
When the other aircraft has reported that it has descended through FL130.
When the other aircraft has reported that it has left FL120.

variant.question: Which of the following defines "FLIGHT VISIBILITY"?

options.text: The forward visibility from the flight deck of an aircraft in flight.
Visibility determined in flight not obscured by cloud, dust, haze or precipitation.
The ability to determine in the air the distance and identity of unlighted objects by day and lighted objects by night.
The forward distance at which objects can be discerned in the air with reference to atmospheric conditions.

variant.question: In accordance with ICAO Annex 2, in areas where a separation minimum of 1 000 ft is applied up to FL410, authorization for VFR flight shall not be granted above which flight level?

options.text: FL290
FL200
FL240
FL190

variant.question: On a VFR flight, your magnetic track is 005°, the magnetic heading 355°. Which of the following flight level is correct?

options.text: FL55
FL65
FL70
FL60

variant.question: Is it possible to choose flying altitude for IFR 2 600 ft AMSL?

options.text: No, because IFR uses whole altitude numbers.
No, because IFR flight levels should be either odd or even numbers.
No, because lowest flight level should be at least 3 000 ft AMSL.
Yes.

variant.question: Where two or more closely spaced aerodromes are located so that coordinated procedures are required, a common transition altitude shall be established as

options.text: the highest of the transition altitudes if the aerodromes were considered separately.
the average of the transition altitudes if the aerodromes were considered separately.
the lowest of the transition altitudes if the aerodromes were considered separately.
one of the transition altitudes commonly agreed between the aerodrome authorities.

variant.question: The purpose of altimeter setting is:

options.text: Provide vertical separation during all phases of flight.
Provide horizontal separation during all phases of flight.
Provide vertical separation and input for SSR ground facilities during all phases of flight.
Provide horizontal separation and clearance during all phases of flight.

variant.question: According to PANS Ops Doc 8168, when should the QNH setting be available to aircraft?

options.text: During the taxi clearance prior to take-off
During the take- off clearance
During the start clearance
During clearance on the stand

variant.question: The transition level is

options.text: the lowest flight level available for use above the transition altitude.
calculated and declared for an approach by the pilot-in command.
the highest available flight level below the transition altitude that has been established.
published for each aerodrome in the AIP, Section MAP.

variant.question: You are flying at FL140 and ATC transmits a clearance to descent to 3 000 ft. The transition level is at FL80. What are you going to do?

options.text: You report in terms of altitude when flying within the transition layer.
You report in terms of flight level when flying within the transition layer.
You report in terms of flight level when passing FL40.
You report in terms of altitude when flying at 14 000 ft and QNH is set.

variant.question: The calculated height of the transition altitude:

options.text: shall be rounded up to the next full 1 000 ft.
shall be rounded down to the next full 1 000 ft.
shall be rounded down to the next full 500 ft.
shall be rounded up to the next full 500 ft.

variant.question: The transition layer is the airspace located...

options.text: between the Transition Level and the Transition Altitude.
below the Transition Altitude.
where the atmospheric pressure equals 1013.2 hPa.
above the Transition Level.

variant.question: According to ICAO Doc 8168, PANS-OPS, the transition altitude is normally specified as a calculated height rounded up to the next full
Which of the following defines Transition Altitude?

options.text: The altitude at which 1 013.2 hPa is set during a climb and vertical position then reported as flight levels.
The altitude below which the vertical position of an aircraft is determined by reference to 1 013.2 hPa.
The altitude above which the vertical position of an aircraft is determined by reference to local QNH.
The altitude below which the vertical position of an aircraft is determined by reference to QFE.

variant.question: Flights at or above the Transition Level, shall be conducted in terms of ___.

options.text: transition altitude.
transition layer.
the level specified by ATC.
transition level.

variant.question: The main objectives for altimeter setting procedures are to provide adequate..

options.text: vertical separation between aircraft and adequate terrain clearance during all phases of a flight.
horizontal separation between aircraft and adequate terrain clearance during all phases of a flight.
horizontal separation between aircraft and input to ACAS equipment.
vertical separation between aircraft and input to ground-based SSR equipment.

variant.question: While passing through the transition layer, an aircraft's vertical position shall be expressed in terms of flight levels when (1) _____ and altitude when (2) _____.

options.text: (1) climbing; (2) descending
(1) en-route; (2) landing
(1) descending; (2) climbing
(1) landing; (2) enroute

variant.question: According to ICAO Doc 8168 PANS-OPS, prior to take-off, one altimeter shall be set on the latest ... (1) altimeter setting for the aerodrome. What is the abbreviation for the missing term?

options.text: QNH
QFE
QNI
QNE

variant.question: Flight above the transition altitude is referenced to:

options.text: flight levels when 1 013 hPa is set.
altitude with reference to local QNH.
flight levels with reference to local QNH.
altitude with reference to the standard atmospheric pressure.

variant.question: What does the abbreviation TA stand for?

options.text: Traffic Advisory and Transition Altitude
Transition Altitude and Terrain Avoidance
Terrain Avoidance and Traffic Advisory
Terminal Altitude and Traffic Advisory

variant.question: When can height be reported as altitude while flying above the transition layer?

options.text: When an approach clearance has been received and descent begun and level flight is NOT expected during descent.
When cleared to descent below transition altitude and while staying within the control zone the entire time.
When cleared to descent below transition altitude while flying above the sea.
During an approach to an airport where no published transition level is available and when visual meteorological conditions exist.

variant.question: Transition from altitude to flight level, and vice-versa is done:

options.text: At transition altitude during climb and transition level during descent.
Only at transition altitude.
At transition level during climb and transition altitude during descent.
Only at transition level.

variant.question: With QFE set a serviceable altimeter will indicate the height of the altimeter in relation to the QFE reference point within a tolerance of:

options.text: ± 20 m for altimeters with a test range of 0 to 30 000 ft.
± 20 m for altimeters with a test range of 0 to 50 000 ft.
± 20 ft for altimeters with a test range of 0 to 30 000 ft.
± 20 ft for altimeters with a test range of 0 to 50 000 ft.

variant.question: In order to avoid confusion, how are transition altitudes set at two aerodromes located close together.

options.text: Higher of the two if considered separately
an average
kept separate
Lower of the two if calculated separately

variant.question: Where the transition altitude is shared between 2 different aerodromes, the common transition altitude shall be:

options.text: The highest between 2 aerodromes.
The average between the 2 aerodromes.
The aerodrome that has more traffic.
The lowest between 2 aerodromes.

variant.question: In the standard atmosphere FL150 is equivalent to:
When should the latest QNH altimeter setting for the aerodrome be obtained?

options.text: Prior to descending below the transition level.
When descending below the transition level.
Prior to descending below the transition altitude.
When descending through the transition layer.

variant.question: During a flight below the Transition Altitude, the altimeter of an aircraft shall be set to:

options.text: QNH and its vertical position expressed in terms of altitude.
QNE and its vertical position expressed in terms of altitude.
QNH and its vertical position expressed in terms of height.
QNE and its vertical position expressed in terms of flight levels.

variant.question: Where shall the transition altitude be published?

options.text: AIP and appropriate charts.
ATIS and AIP only.
ATIS and AIP and appropriate charts.
ATIS and appropriate charts.

variant.question: According to PANS ATM DOC 4444 when should the QNH be available for arriving aircraft?

options.text: In approach clearances and traffic circuit joining instructions.
When cleared to the FAF.
When leaving the cruising level.
In approach and landing clearances.

variant.question:
Transition altitude: 3 000 ft
QNH: **990** hPa
Calculate transition level:

options.text: FL 40
FL 20
FL 25
FL 35

variant.question: According to ICAO Doc 8168, PANS-OPS, Transition Altitudes shall be

options.text: published in aeronautical information publications, and shown on the appropriate charts.
shown on the appropriate charts, and included in ATIS broadcasts.
published in aeronautical information publications, shown on the appropriate charts, and included in ATIS broadcasts.
published in aeronautical information publications, and included in ATIS broadcasts.

variant.question: An aircraft is maintaining FL150 within airspace class C. Another aircraft below at FL140 is receiving a clearance to descend to FL70. It is severe turbulence in the area. What is the earliest time that a clearance to descend to FL140 or below can be expected?

options.text: When the other aircraft has reported that it has descended through FL130.
When the other aircraft has reported that it has left FL120.
When the other aircraft has reported that it has left FL140.
When the other aircraft has reported that it has reached FL70.

variant.question: Which of the following is true concerning the Transition Altitude?

options.text: 2 minutes.
5 minutes.
3 minutes.
1 minute.

variant.question: At least how many NM shall a Control Zone extend from a reference point of the aerodrome or aerodromes into the direction from which approaches may be made?

options.text: 5 NM
7.5 NM
10 NM
12 NM

variant.question: If ATC realises they are unable to maintain adequate horizontal separation between IFR traffic at the same altitude, what are they going to do?

options.text: ATC will vector such aircraft to different flight levels to provide vertical separation.
ATC will ask the flight crew with TCAS capabilities to rely on the TCAS and to maintain their own separation.
ATC will reduce the horizontal separation to half of the prescribed minima.
ATC will advise the flight crew to employ visual separation.

variant.question: An aircraft is at FL330 and about to decend. How and when is the aircraft informed about the transition level?

options.text: By ATIS and within sufficient time before descending through the transition level (10 000 ft).
At 3 000 ft, by ATC.
At any altitude, by VORTAC.
At 2 500 ft, by data link.

variant.question: Altimeter setting procedures – The transition level..

options.text: is normally an integrated part of the ATIS.
has to be calculated by the Pilot-in command.
is published on the approach and landing chart for each aerodrome.
is published and if necessary updated in the NOTAM.

variant.question: A transition altitude shall normally be specified for each aerodrome by the State in which the aerodrome is located. The calculated height of the transition altitude shall be rounded up to the next full:

options.text: 50 ft.

variant.question: Two aircraft are flying to Paris. Aircraft A takes off from London Heathrow and is in front of aircraft B with 1 minute difference. Aircraft B from London centre at the same direction, 150 (M) inbound Paris Charles de Gaulle VOR for holding procedure before landing. What will be the separation of altitude flight level?

options.text: FL250 aircraft A and FL270 aircraft B
FL240 aircraft A and FL260 aircraft B
FL260 aircraft A and FL240 aircraft B
FL270 aircraft A and FL250 aircraft B

variant.question: What is the vertical separation between 2 aircraft flying on the same airway in the same direction above FL290 in an area where RVSM is not applied?
According to ICAO Doc 8168 PANS-OPS, for aircraft approaching a controlled aerodrome for landing, the QNH altimeter setting shall be made available..

options.text: in approach clearances and in clearances to enter the traffic circuit.
in approach and landing clearances, on request or on a regular basis.
during the intermediate approach segment.
prior to leaving the en-route cruising level.

variant.question: Refer to ICAO Doc **8168** PANS-OPS. Flight level zero shall be located at the atmospheric pressure level of 1 013.2 hPa. Consecutive flight levels shall be separated by a pressure interval corresponding to at least ___ in the standard atmosphere.

options.text: 500 ft
300 ft

variant.question: How is 'FLIGHT VISIBILITY' defined?

options.text: The visibility forward from the flight deck of an aircraft in flight.
The measured visibility assessed by a certified meteorological observer.
The forecast visibility at 3 000 ft above the aerodrome.
The visibility reported by a pilot currently flying in the vicinity.

variant.question: "3-BAR AVASIS", "PAPI" and "T-VASIS" shall be provided for aircraft having eye-to-wheel heights, when in the flare altitude, not exceeding:

options.text: approximately 16 m.
approximately 15 m.
approximately 18 m.
approximately 14 m.
